13 A summary of damage and restoration to the cathedral glass, not without error, is in Les vitraux de Champagne-Ardenne, 384, 386. The chief loss to the grisailles was in the lowest panels, which (like those of all the clerestories) were removed for the coronations of Louis XIV and Louis XV, and no doubt previously. For the coronation of Charles X in 1825, the grisailles were colored with oil paint

container-title: See Louis Grodecki in Les vitraux de Notre-Dame et de la Sainte-Chapelle de Paris, Corpus Vitrearum Medii Aevi, France 1

The glazing of the triforium and clerestory of the Tours Cathedral chevet probably replicates the two stories of the Sainte-Chapelle, as does their architecture. See Robert Branner, St. Louis and the Court Style in Gothic Architecture
title: While the lower chapel is quite dark, the apsidal bays almost certainly were glazed with large, fully colored figures, and the series continued in the surviving painting of the Annunciation in the blind bay on the north: Robert Branner, The Painted Medallions in the Sainte-Chapelle in Paris
The glass of the lower chapel was replaced after the flood of 1690 and is now nineteenth century

note: I prefer to take eye-witnesses Henri Sauval and Pierre Le Vieil (see ibid., 16–17) at their word that the nave bays were grisailles, probably with colored fillets as in Chartres Cathedral Bay 19 (Delaporte Bay 44, ca. 1235–1240; see note 26 below).
